content.description:
A continuous and aesthetic fist to offwidth crack scaling the entire height of the easternmost cliff on the shady north-facing side of the butte. Commit to the 5.8 thin-fist crux about twenty feet off the deck and then cruise up the featured offwidth for the remainder of the pitch. Pure fun! 

  Some obviously loose blocks were pulled off the route prior to the first ascent, but be aware that there could still be friable rock in places. Test suspect holds before yarding on them.
content.protection:
Use earth anchors set back from the cliff a ways to rig up a top rope. The climb itself takes mostly size 3-4 Camalots, but there is a small horizontal break above the crux that will take finger sized cams. 

  WARNING: For your safety, please do *not* place pro behind the right-leaning flake/crack guarding the top of the crux.
content.location: Park in the big gravel patch just north-west of the easternmost (smaller) radio tower. Squeeze through the very cool narrow slot chimney and downclimb a few 4th class moves to get to the base of the cliff (alternately, scramble down the scree a little further west), then follow the wall about 30 feet east.

content.description: Fun crack climb with sketchy placements.
content.protection: Standard traditional rock.  Top rope possible if you have trad gear to set up an anchor.  Weak rock that could easily result in gear pulling out during a fall.
content.location: The crack is located about 10 ft. left of Unknown 5.8.

content.description: Sandstone with rock that breaks off easily, top rope anchors should be inspected.
content.protection: Top rope anchors over the top of the climb.  Check thoroughly before using
content.location: On the arete to the left of Hell's Heaven

content.description: A tricky opening sequence leads to plenty of crimping fun. Easier toward top.
content.location: bolt line to the right of Hell's Heaven. This one has regular bolt hangers (or maybe it was glue-ins), Hell's Heaven has cold shuts as the hangers.

content.description: A sustained vertical finger crack with the occasional hand jam and face hold to shake out on. Fun and pumpy for the area.
content.protection: Thin finger to hand-size cams and a few nuts. There is a pair of old quarter-inch buttonhead bolts at the top missing hangers, presumably installed by the first ascensionist(s).
content.location: On the south-facing side of the main (western) summit, near where the power lines run off the top and directly south of the first "main" building and propane tank you see upon arriving at the top of the Butte.

content.description: Sandstone route.  Not the most exciting, but you're in ND.
content.protection: 5 bolts and top anchors.  If leading, inspect the anchors thoroughly before use.
content.location: To the right of the arete containing Unknown 5.8.

content.description: Chicken wing and smear your way up the fifteen foot vertical section before pulling the roof using jugs and stems. Cruise to the top.
content.location: On the south-facing side of the main (western) summit, near where the power lines run off the top and directly south of the first "main" building and propane tank you see upon arriving at the top of the Butte.

content.description: Fun route. Route stays a little left of the bolts. Good anchors up top
content.location: Bolts to the R of the Great Roof

content.description:
The routes are on top of Sentinel Butte, not in the town.  Sandstone rock that is brittle.  Bolted in 2003 with expansion bolts and should be inspected before use.  The land is privately owned. Don't leave a mess!  Somewhat of a tourist attraction 

Update 2017:

  The owner minds climbers being on his land. A LOT. We're working on gaining climber access at the moment but it will be a journey.  

  Until then, this area is closed to climbers unless otherwise noted.
